title: 114_hr6278
content:
The "Promote Accountability and Government Efficiency Act" includes provisions such as at-will employment status for new Federal employees, immediate suspension for misconduct, limitation on appeal rights, restriction of pay raises, forfeiture of annuity for felony convictions, transfer from Senior Executive Service to General Schedule, and limitation on union activities. The "Promote Accountability and Government Efficiency Act" establishes at-will employment for new Federal employees, allowing their removal or suspension without notice or appeal. It clarifies that equal employment opportunities and rights remain protected under existing laws. Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibits discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin. The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 prohibits age discrimination. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 prohibits sex discrimination. The Rehabilitation Act of 1973 prohibits discrimination based on handicapping condition. The Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act of 2012 protects whistleblowers. Various laws prohibit discrimination based on marital status or political affiliation. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 also addresses discrimination issues. The curr_chunk discusses the appeal process for employees or applicants seeking remedies under various laws related to adverse personnel actions, including the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995, prohibited personnel practices, and laws protecting veterans' employment rights. Employees can seek remedies under title 5 of the United States Code, such as appealing to the Merit Systems Protection Board or the Office of the Special Counsel. Employees or applicants can appeal adverse personnel actions to a single agency, such as the Merit Systems Protection Board or the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, under certain laws. They cannot appeal the same dismissal to another agency. This applies to employees hired one year after the enactment of the Act, and agencies must develop operating standards within 180 days. The section outlines standards for notifying at-will employees, determining authority for separation, and ensuring oversight to prevent discrimination. Definitions include "employee" as per section 2105 of title 5, and "personnel action." The section defines "personnel action" and "veteran" according to specific sections of title 5. SEC. 3. Immediate suspension of employees for misconduct or poor performance is added to Chapter 75 of title 5, United States Code. ``Sec. 7551. Definitions: 
- `Employee' defined as per section 7501(1), includes USPS and Postal Regulatory Commission employees, excluding at-will employees.
- `Suspend' means placing an employee on temporary duty-free status for misconduct or poor performance.

Sec. 7552. Immediate suspension for misconduct or poor performance: 
- Agency head can suspend an employee (with or without pay) under OPM regulations if misconduct or performance warrants it. Duration of suspension determined by the head. An employee can be suspended by the agency head for misconduct or poor performance, with or without pay. The employee is entitled to a written notice stating reasons for suspension, a chance to respond with evidence, representation by an attorney, and a review by the agency head with a final decision. The employee can appeal to the Merit Systems Protection Board. During an appeal to the Merit Systems Protection Board, the employee cannot be reinstated until a final decision is made. Copies of relevant documents must be provided to the Board and the affected employee upon request. In cases of critical necessity, the agency head can immediately replace a suspended employee without following certain procedures. (b) Clerical Amendment.--The table of sections for chapter 75 of title 5, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following: SEC. 4. LIMITATION ON APPEAL RIGHTS. An employee or applicant for employment may not appeal an adverse personnel action to more than 1 agency. SEC. 5. RESTRICTION OF PAY RAISES. The text chunk outlines limitations on pay raises for employees based on performance reviews, a requirement for a report on a single-agency rating system, and the application of these rules to collective bargaining agreements. The text outlines limitations on pay raises for employees based on performance reviews under collective bargaining agreements. The term "employee" includes individuals from the United States Postal Service or the Postal Regulatory Commission. Employees convicted of a felony may forfeit their CSRS or FERS annuity. Employees convicted of a felony may forfeit their annuity or retired pay if the offense is related to their position within the service. Employees convicted of a felony may lose their annuity if the offense is related to their government service. The term 'finally convicted' is defined in section 8332(o)(A)(6) of the United States Code. Employees convicted of a felony related to their government service may forfeit their annuity. The amendment allows the transfer of Senior Executive Service employees to General Schedule positions with corresponding pay rates. The amendment allows the transfer of Senior Executive Service employees to General Schedule positions with corresponding pay rates, including at-will employees under the Promote Accountability and Government Efficiency Act. A clerical amendment was made to the table of sections in the United States Code. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON OFFICIAL TIME AND USE OF GOVERNMENT RESOURCES IN CARRYING OUT UNION ACTIVITIES. Amends Section 7131 of title 5, United States Code to restrict employees from using official time or government resources for labor organization activities.
